profileText: A Senator from Wisconsin; born in Fond du Lac, Fond du Lac County, Wis., June 23, 1888; attended the public schools; graduated from the University of Wisconsin at Madison, in 1910 and from its law department in 1912; admitted to the bar in 1912 and commenced practice in Fond du Lac, Wis.; during the First World War served in the United States Army 1917-1919, attaining the rank of major; resumed the practice of law in Fond du Lac, Wis.; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate and served from March 4, 1933, to January 3, 1939; unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1938; again resumed the practice of law before becoming United States district judge for the eastern district of Wisconsin, serving from 1939 to 1949, when he qualified as a United States circuit judge of the court of appeals for the seventh circuit, becoming chief judge in 1954, serving until 1959; retired as a full-time member of the court in 1966 and assumed the status of senior judge and continued to hear cases for several more years; died in Milwaukee, Wis., August 16, 1979; interment in Calvary Cemetery, Fond du Lac, Wis.

researchRecord.name: 1906-1979. 10.4 cubic feet, 1 tape recording, 3 microfilm reels. Includes biographical material, correspondence, campaign material, legislative and judicial files, and speeches. Biographical material includes daybooks and diaries (1935-1970), a 1973 interview, and numerous microfilmed scrapbooks. Correspondence (1933-1973) deals with his law firm, honors, politics, personal matters, reunions, and trips. Senate correspondence includes files on issues, patronage and legislation, especially copyright legislation. Judicial files (1939-1973) include term calendars, case files, correspondence, records on a judicial bankruptcy committee, and notes and instructions. Finding aid.
Correspondence in Theodore Herfurth papers, 1894-1950; Leonard B. Von Spach papers, 1919-1968; and John K. Kyle papers, 1925-1964.
1932-1964. 25 feet. Includes correspondence, speeches, opinions, diaries, and scrapbooks.

recordLocation.name: Milwaukee Area Research Center University of Wisconsin
